qas.question: How many ways does the Mimamsa separate into subschools?
How many ways does the Prabhakara subschool of Mimamsa say there are to gain knowledge?
How is pratyaksa defined in the Prabhakara subschool?
What is the word for inference in the Prabhakara subschool?
What is comparison and analogy in the Prabhakara school?
What means did the Kumarila Bhatta remove from its canon?
What subschool only uses four reliable means?
How many Mimamsa subschools are not defined by epistemology?

context: The <b5_0>Mīmāṃsā<b5_0/> school has <a0_0><b9_0>several<b9_0/><a0_0/> subschools defined by epistemology. The <b7_0>Prābhākara<b7_0/> subschool of Mīmāṃsā considered <a1_0>five<a1_0/> epistemically reliable means to gaining knowledge: pratyakṣa (<a2_0>perception<a2_0/>), <a3_0>anumāṇa<a3_0/> (inference), <a4_0>upamāṇa<a4_0/> (comparison and analogy), arthāpatti (postulation, derivation from circumstances), and śabda (word, testimony of past or present reliable experts). The Kumārila Bhaṭṭa sub-school of Mīmāṃsā added sixth to its canon of reliable epistemology - <b6_0><b8_0>anupalabdi<b8_0/><b6_0/> (non-perception, negative/cognitive proof).
